docs.lead_paragraph: In a windowless room two stories below ground level, Lyudmila Zavlyanova sits in what could be a scene from the cold war. People are hunched in front of computers in cramped cubicles, speaking to each other in hushed tones in Russian. But they are in New Jersey and this is an entirely different kind of global struggle: the code war.

headline.main: TRILLION-DOLLAR DIGITS: A special report.; Computers and 2000: Race for Security

docs.abstract: Insuring that computers will be able to function in year 2000 is proving more difficult and expensive than most experts expected; Y2K bug has already drained hundreds of billions of dollars from companies and governments; 40 percent of largest American and European companies are already experiencing at least minor breakdowns because some software cannot deal with dates in 2000 and beyond, and another spate of disruptions is expected on first day of 1999; Russian immigrant programmers are especially qualified for job of digging out potential problems because they are conversant in Cobol, the computer language that runs many of America's mainframe computers but is so old that relatively few American programmers know it; photos; drawings (L)
docs.snippet: In a windowless room two stories below ground level, Lyudmila Zavlyanova sits in what could be a scene from the cold war. People are hunched in front of computers in cramped cubicles, speaking to each other in hushed tones in Russian.    But they are...

byline.original: By BARNABY J. FEDER and ANDREW POLLACK

docs.lead_paragraph: In October, New Jersey's fourth-largest health maintenance organization collapsed, threatening the medical coverage of nearly 200,000 people and leaving hospitals and doctors holding the bag for nearly $120 million in unpaid claims. The collapse was the first of its kind in New Jersey, and it has been attributed to a number of factors -- from poor management to increased competition to inadequate financing. But state officials and financial experts say it could have been avoided if the state had been able to examine the books of the company that bought the right to run the H.M.O.'s health centers and physicians' network. Yet, the state's inability to examine the buyer's finances was its own fault, a result of regulations that did not keep up with the rapid changes in managed care.

headline.main: Failed H.M.O. Exposes Shortcomings in a Changing Industry

docs.abstract: Collapse of HIP Health Plan of New Jersey has been attributed to number of factors, from poor management to increased competition to inadequate financing; but state officials and financial experts say collapse could have been avoided if state had been able to examine books of company that bought rights to run the HMO's health centers and physicians' network; say regulations did not keep up with rapid changes in managed care; HIP-NJ's former partner, Pinnacle Health Enterprises, is now in bankruptcy liquidation proceedings and its parent company, PHP Healthcare Inc is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization; chart of HIP-NJ finances; photo (M)

byline.original: By RONALD SMOTHERS and CHRISTOPHER DREW

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Too Much of a Good Thing'' (editorial, Dec. 23): By precisely controlling the number of embryos transferred back to the uterus, in-vitro fertilization solves the problem of high-order multiple births resulting from the use of powerful fertility drugs. But many insurance companies refuse to cover the procedure, even when they cover other treatments that use fertility drugs.
docs.abstract: Edward B Horch letter, commenting on Dec 23 editorial, says insurance companies should be required to cover in-vitro fertilization, which solves the problem of high-order multiple births; cartoon

docs.lead_paragraph: At the age of 10, Switzerland's new President-elect the first woman and first Jew in the largely ceremonial top post -- first put into practice her determined approach to overcoming obstacles. It was 1950 when the new President-elect, Ruth Dreifuss, encountered a teacher who made slighting comments about Jews. In a notebook, she wrote down, in some detail, the history of the Jewish people and their persecution. Taking it to the teacher, she said: ''I'm weak in spelling. Could you correct this?''

headline.main: A First For Swiss: A Woman As President

docs.abstract: Ruth Dreifuss, Switzerland's Interior Minister, is elected President, becoming the first woman and first Jew to hold the largely ceremonial post; calls for honest reappraisal of country's conduct during World War II, but says Swiss ought not accept collective fault for actions of Swiss banks (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The life of every seriously ill child is shrouded in mystery. A clinic visit will reveal symptoms: a runny nose, congested breathing, deteriorating weight. But it is hard to determine in a half-hour visit what other details about a child's life might be contributing to obvious health problems.

headline.main: Once Again, A Doctor Is in the House; Home Visits Help Reveal Stories Behind Illnesses

docs.abstract: Dr Alex Okun, associate professor of clinical pediatrics at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, is one of small number pediatricians who make regular house calls; Okun holds that visiting homes can reveal details about children's lives that may be contributing to their health problems; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AMERICAN troops in the Persian Gulf are vaccinated against deadly germs. So are Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who are probing a growing number of biological incidents. So are some White House officials. Protections against living weapons are new to the military and security of the United States, and they raise troubling questions.

headline.main: The Threat of Germ Weapons Is Rising. Fear, Too.

docs.abstract: Rising concern over germ warfare threat discussed; United States officials are taking issue seriously, quietly erecting defenses, while stressing they know of no imminent danger; germ weapons, though hard to make and use, are far cheaper than other weapons of mass destruction and more frightening; secrets of germ warfare are increasingly available as weapons scientists from nations with biological arsenals seek new jobs; photos (M)

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD and JUDITH MILLER

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Too Much of a Good Thing'' (editorial, Dec. 23): Although the short- and long-term prognosis for the survival and health of the octuplets is guarded, it is certain that the costs associated with the obstetrical and pediatric medical care for these babies will be millions of dollars. Had Nkem Chukwu, the mother of the octuplets, been treated with in-vitro fertilization instead of fertility drugs, a high-order multiple birth could have been prevented. It is likely, however, that Ms. Chukwu's insurance did not cover in-vitro fertilization.
docs.abstract: Daniel Kenigsberg letter, commenting on Dec 23 editorial on birth of octuplets in Houston, says number of high-order multiple births could be reduced if insurance companies covered in-vitro fertilization; says their refusal to cover it drives couples to fertility drugs; cartoon

docs.lead_paragraph: WALTER A. ZELMAN, a self-described health policy wonk and a sometime composer of political-parody ditties, wrote a song about Jerry Brown, the former California Governor, who was running for President against Bill Clinton in 1992. ''He's Jerry Brown and he's always a-changin','' Mr. Zelman sang, borrowing, presciently as it turned out, from ''The Times They Are A-Changin,' '' the Bob Dylan anthem. Last month, in his latest metamorphosis, Mr. Brown was elected Mayor of Oakland.

headline.main: Playing a New Health Care Tune

docs.abstract: Article profiles Walter A Zelman, former consumer health-care advocate and member of Hillary Rodham Clinton's health policy team, who has been named president and chief executive of California Assn of Health Plans, a managed-care lobby; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Insurance companies and employers have found ways to get around a 1996 law that requires them to offer health care coverage for mental illness that is comparable to that for physical illness. The law, the Mental Health Parity Act, was expected to make mental health care more readily available to millions of Americans, but, experts on employee benefits and health policy say, it has not.

headline.main: INSURANCE PLANS SKIRT REQUIREMENT ON MENTAL HEALTH

docs.abstract: Insurance companies and employers find ways to get around Mental Health Parity Act of 1996, which requires them to offer health care coverage for mental illness that is comparable to that for physical illness; law outlaws dollar limits on coverage, but many group plans have simply replaced them with numerical limits on outpatient visits, treatment sessions or days in the hospitals; numerical limits are more restrictive than dollar limits in some cases; some plans also set higher co-payments and deductibles for mental health care than for other medical services, a disparity allowed under the law; supporters of law say they will fight to broaden and strengthen it in 1999 (M)
docs.snippet: Insurance companies and employers have found ways to get around a 1996 law that requires them to offer health care coverage for mental illness that is comparable to that for physical illness.     The law, the Mental Health Parity Act, was expected to...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Russia and Belarus Plan a Unified Currency The Presidents of Russia and Belarus said they intended to begin unifying their currencies and much of their economies next year. That would stop just short of a political merger that would again extend Russian territory to the border of Poland. President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, above, said he hoped that the two countries would enter the millennium as one. A1
